thread.title_full: Talented cast takes on 'Carrie, The Musical' at Brunish Theatre (review) | OregonLive.com

author: Lee Williams | Special to The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Talented cast takes on 'Carrie, The Musical' at Brunish Theatre (review)
text:
As wallflower-turned-prom-queen Carrie White takes the stage next to her prom king, you tense up.
Near her, a string, tied to a bucket of pig's blood, jiggles.
A crown is placed on Carrie's head.
You know what's coming next, but — like Cornwall clawing out Gloucester's eyes, like Drew Barrymore answering that first phone call in "Scream" — you still hold your breath.
And then the bloodbath.
Even though Stumptown Stages' production strangely obscures the iconic bucket with a prom banner, and the blood that douses Carrie is indicated through crimson lights, the climax of "Carrie, The Musical" is surprisingly effective.
That's not to say the musical is scary -- or required viewing for anyone but musical theater geeks who want a peek at what's generally regarded as the biggest Broadway musical flop of all time .
The show, which opened Friday at the Brunish Theatre, is a 2012 off-Broadway reboot of the famous 1988 disaster that ran for only five performances against a then-staggering $8 million budget.
In this version of the Stephen King chiller, the bullying is played up, Carrie's mother is overly sympathetic, and the scares, the gore and a lot of the suspense are drastically reduced.
It's a big time for King on stage: A new, audience-immersive version called " Carrie: The Killer Musical Experience ," is currently running in Los Angeles; and a non-musical adaptation of King's "Misery," starring Bruce Willis and Laurie Metcalf , began previews this month at the Broadhurst Theatre on Broadway.
What keeps this show afloat, through a clunky book and ballad-heavy score, is the sheer will and talent of the kids in the cast, who actually look and act like high school students and power through the material convinced that it's meaningful.
Line of the Night: "Everyone isn't bad, momma. Everything's not a sin," Carrie says to her mother, after being told she can't go to the prom.
Strengths: The kids are more than all right. Ranging from a first-time professional performer (Jake Daley as Tommy) to a young vet who toured with "Evita" (Malia Davis, here playing Carrie), the young cast is in strong voice, and in good step with director/choreographer Kirk Mouser's moves.
Malia Davis plays the title role in "Carrie, The Musical." Paul Fardig/Stumptown Stages The play is reset in 2012, and Evan Tait, as Billy, puts a current, emo-thug spin on the John Travolta role from the 1976 movie. He also lands some smartass ad-libs that diffuse the oh-so-serious script.
Playing supreme mean girl Chris, Carrie Morgan breathes malevolence and belts out sure notes.
It's eerie how closely Amber Mitchell, as Sue, resembles Amy Irving from the movie, and how she convincingly morphs from mean girl to human.
Davis's Carrie is more anxious than meek — an interesting take. Under her frumpy hand-me-down layers, she's full of wincing, nervous energy, as if constant bullying has set her to permanent fight-or-flight mode.
Weaknesses: Originally, Margaret White was terrifying. As written by King and played by Piper Laurie in the film, she was a volatile zealot who believed in modern day witches and spewed Old Testament hellfire. In this rendering, Margaret (Susan Jonsson) is defanged through four mawkish ballads. That she's no longer frightening removes a big point of conflict in Carrie's arc, and her mother's filicide, then, doesn't square up. You just don't swap out Medea with Maria von Trapp.
Composed by Dean Pitchford and Michael Gore, who crafted pop hits and Oscar-winning movie themes in the '80s, "Carrie's" score should be much stronger and catchier.
"Carrie," which introduces the lead, is a syrupy-sweet number that should be haunting and foreshadowing. "And Eve Was Weak," where Margaret agonizes over Carrie getting her period — "the curse of the blood" — is set to a booming "Sweeney Todd"-style arrangement. It comes off satirical and silly, like an overture to "Change, Change, Change (Change of Life)", the opening number from "Menopause The Musical."
And do these lyrics from the song "Carrie" sound familiar?
"I am a song of endless wonder/That no one will claim/But someday, oh my, someday!/ Someone will know my name!"
Turns out, Pitchford and Gore wrote pretty much the same lines for the chorus of "Fame," their 1980 Oscar-winner for Best Song:
"I'm gonna make it to heaven/Light up the sky like a flame/ "I'm gonna live forever/Baby, remember my name"
Take-away: Talented teens and twentysomethings take on Broadway's biggest musical bomb. They're terrific. The show's still a bloody mess. But admit it: You kind of want to go, don't you?
— Lee Williams for The Oregonian/OregonLive
 ***
"Carrie, the Musical"
 Where: Brunish Theatre, 1111 S.W. Broadway Ave., Portland
When: 7:30 p.m. Thursdays-Saturdays and 2 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays through Nov. 8
Tickets: $25 - $40; www.Portland5.com or www.stumptownstages.org ; 503-381-8686
